ground_truth: Gandhi stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall in the East End of London, being greeted by a cheering crowd, with the now gray-haired Charlie Andrews beaming possessively at his side. Gandhi, dressed in his dhoti, waves to a small crowd as he enters the gates of Buckingham Palace. He takes his seat at the conference table among the formally dressed delegates, some Maharajahs elaborately so. A gavel is struck, and Ramsay MacDonald begins his opening address, wearing his white suit and black-ribboned pince-nez. Gandhi sits on a wicker chair with Nehru and Patel leaning against the railing, while Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor like Gandhi. As Gandhi winds up what he has done and starts to rise, he moves toward the steps, stops, and looks at Patel with a wry, gentle smile before looking at Jinnah and shrugging. Jinnah takes it less philosophically, and his eyes burn with anger as he watches Gandhi head for the young girl with the injured goat. Gandhi moves with the stream of passengers disembarking from the Third Class section, with Ba and Mirabehn struggling along behind him, accompanied by Desai and Pyarelal. A British captain stands before a full platoon of Indian troops, and as Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant move out from one side of the troops. Gandhi stops, looks up at him and the troops, then shakes his head with a weary grin. The British Colonel signals back to the troops, and as a detail marches up, the colonel's adjutant speaks gently to Ba, who stares at him belligerently, leaving him flummoxed. The colonel and his adjutant stride toward the exit of the station, followed by a detail of six soldiers accompanying Gandhi, then another detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba, and another accompanying Mirabehn. A jeep driven by an American lieutenant with a woman dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform, Margaret Bourke-White, as the passenger, bounces along the road. As the jeep passes the camera, the view pans to see the walls of a palace ahead, with Bourke-White staring at the palace, absorbing the experience with the appetite of her breed and her own particular sensitivity. Gandhi sits by a window that is grilled rather than barred, spinning in a shaft of light and looking off, as the sound of a camera click and the rustle of movement is heard, while his hair, only half-gray in London, is now white.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall in the East End of London, being greeted by a cheering throng, with the now gray-haired Charlie Andrews beaming possessively at his flank. Gandhi, attired in his dhoti, waves to a small gathering as he enters the portals of Buckingham Palace. He takes his seat at the conference table among the formally attired envoys, some Maharajahs elaborately so. A gavel is struck, and Ramsay MacDonald begins his opening oration, wearing his alabaster suit and black-ribboned pince-nez. Gandhi sits on a wicker chair with Nehru and Patel leaning against the railing, while Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor like Gandhi. As Gandhi winds up what he has accomplished and starts to rise, he moves toward the steps, halts, and gazes at Patel with a wry, gentle grin before regarding Jinnah and shrugging. Jinnah takes it less philosophically, and his eyes blaze with ire as he watches Gandhi head for the young girl with the injured goat. Gandhi maneuvers with the stream of travelers disembarking from the Third Class section, with Ba and Mirabehn struggling along behind him, accompanied by Desai and Pyarelal. A British captain stands before a full platoon of Indian soldiers, and as Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant move out from one flank of the soldiers. Gandhi stops, looks up at him and the soldiers, then shakes his head with a weary smirk. The British Colonel signals back to the soldiers, and as a detail marches up, the colonel's adjutant speaks gently to Ba, who stares at him belligerently, leaving him perplexed. The colonel and his adjutant stride toward the exit of the station, followed by a detail of six troopers accompanying Gandhi, then another detail of six troopers accompanying Ba, and another accompanying Mirabehn. A jeep driven by an American lieutenant with a woman attired in an American War Correspondent's uniform, Margaret Bourke-White, as the passenger, bounces along the road. As the jeep passes the camera, the view pans to see the walls of a palace ahead, with Bourke-White staring at the palace, absorbing the experience with the appetite of her breed and her own particular sensitivity. Gandhi sits by a window that is grilled rather than barred, spinning in a shaft of illumination and looking off, as the sound of a camera click and the rustle of movement is heard, while his hair, only half-gray in London, is now alabaster.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall in London's East End, greeted by a cheering crowd, with gray-haired Charlie Andrews beaming beside him. Gandhi, in his dhoti, waves to a small crowd at Buckingham Palace. He sits at a conference table with formally dressed delegates, including elaborately dressed Maharajahs. Ramsay MacDonald, in a white suit and black-ribboned pince-nez, begins his address. Gandhi sits on a wicker chair with Nehru and Patel nearby, while Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor. As Gandhi concludes, he rises, smiles wryly at Patel, glances at Jinnah, and shrugs. Jinnah, less philosophical, watches angrily as Gandhi approaches a girl with an injured goat. Gandhi disembarks from the Third Class section with Ba, Mirabehn, Desai, and Pyarelal. A British captain stands before Indian troops; a British Lt. Colonel and Adjutant approach Gandhi, who shakes his head with a weary grin. The Colonel signals the troops, and a detail marches up. The Adjutant speaks to Ba, who stares belligerently, leaving him flummoxed. The Colonel and Adjutant exit the station, followed by soldiers accompanying Gandhi, Ba, and Mirabehn. An American lieutenant drives a jeep with War Correspondent Margaret Bourke-White, who absorbs the palace view ahead. Gandhi sits by a grilled window, spinning in light, as a camera clicks and movement rustles, his hair now white.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands on Kingsley Hall steps in London, greeted by a cheering crowd, with gray-haired Charlie Andrews beside him. Gandhi, in his dhoti, waves to a small crowd at Buckingham Palace. He sits at a conference table with formally dressed delegates, including elaborately dressed Maharajahs. Ramsay MacDonald, in a white suit and pince-nez, begins his address. Gandhi sits on a wicker chair with Nehru and Patel nearby, while Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor. As Gandhi concludes, he smiles at Patel, then shrugs at Jinnah, who watches angrily. Gandhi disembarks with Ba and Mirabehn, followed by Desai and Pyarelal. A British captain and Lt. Colonel approach Gandhi, who shakes his head with a grin. The colonel signals troops, and his adjutant speaks to Ba, who stares belligerently. Soldiers accompany Gandhi, Ba, and Mirabehn. An American lieutenant drives a jeep with War Correspondent Margaret Bourke-White, who observes a palace. Gandhi spins by a window, his hair now white, as a camera clicks.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands with quiet dignity on the steps of Kingsley Hall, located in the bustling East End of London, where he is warmly greeted by an enthusiastic and cheering crowd. Beside him, the now gray-haired Charlie Andrews beams with a sense of possessive pride. Gandhi, clad in his simple dhoti, waves graciously to the small but eager crowd as he makes his way through the gates of the grand Buckingham Palace. Inside, he takes his place at the conference table, surrounded by formally dressed delegates, some of whom are Maharajahs adorned in elaborate attire. The sound of a gavel striking the table signals the beginning of the proceedings, as Ramsay MacDonald, dressed in a crisp white suit and wearing black-ribboned pince-nez, commences his opening address. Gandhi sits comfortably on a wicker chair, with Nehru and Patel casually leaning against the railing nearby, while Azad and Kripalani sit cross-legged on the floor, mirroring Gandhi's posture. As Gandhi concludes his remarks and begins to rise, he pauses on the steps, casting a wry, gentle smile at Patel before turning his gaze to Jinnah and offering a nonchalant shrug. Jinnah, however, does not take it as lightly, and his eyes burn with visible anger as he watches Gandhi make his way toward a young girl tending to an injured goat. Gandhi moves along with the flow of passengers disembarking from the Third Class section, with Ba and Mirabehn struggling to keep up behind him, accompanied by Desai and Pyarelal. A British captain stands at attention before a full platoon of Indian troops, and as Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant step out from one side of the assembled troops. Gandhi halts, looks up at the officer and the troops, then shakes his head with a weary but amused grin. The British Colonel signals to the troops, and as a detail marches forward, the colonel's adjutant speaks gently to Ba, who stares back at him with a belligerent expression, leaving him momentarily flummoxed. The colonel and his adjutant stride purposefully toward the station's exit, followed by a detail of six soldiers escorting Gandhi, another detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba, and yet another detail accompanying Mirabehn. A jeep, driven by an American lieutenant with a woman dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform, Margaret Bourke-White, as the passenger, bounces along the road. As the jeep passes by the camera, the view pans to reveal the imposing walls of a palace ahead, with Bourke-White gazing intently at the palace, absorbing the experience with the keen appetite of her profession and her own unique sensitivity. Gandhi sits by a window that is grilled rather than barred, spinning in a shaft of light and gazing thoughtfully into the distance, as the sound of a camera click and the rustle of movement are heard, while his hair, which was only half-gray during his time in London, is now completely white.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Gandhi, embodying a quiet yet profound sense of dignity, stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall, which is situated in the vibrant and bustling East End of London. Here, he is warmly greeted by a crowd that is both enthusiastic and cheering, their energy palpable. Standing beside him is Charlie Andrews, whose hair has now turned gray with age. He beams at Gandhi with a sense of possessive pride that is unmistakable. Gandhi, dressed in his characteristically simple dhoti, waves graciously to the small but eager crowd, acknowledging their warmth, as he makes his way towards the grand and opulent Buckingham Palace. Once inside the palace, he takes his place at the long conference table, surrounded by formally dressed delegates. Among them are several Maharajahs, resplendent in their elaborate attire. The proceedings are signaled to begin by the sharp sound of a gavel striking the table, as Ramsay MacDonald, dressed impeccably in a crisp white suit and donning black-ribboned pince-nez, steps forward to commence his opening address. Gandhi sits comfortably on a wicker chair, exuding calm, while Nehru and Patel casually lean against the nearby railing. Azad and Kripalani sit cross-legged on the floor, mirroring Gandhi's relaxed posture. As Gandhi finishes his remarks and starts to rise, he pauses momentarily on the steps, casting a wry yet gentle smile at Patel before shifting his gaze to Jinnah, offering a nonchalant shrug. However, Jinnah does not take this gesture lightly, and his eyes burn with visible anger as he watches Gandhi make his way towards a young girl who is tending to an injured goat. Gandhi moves along with the flow of passengers who are disembarking from the Third Class section, with Ba and Mirabehn struggling to keep up with him from behind, accompanied by Desai and Pyarelal. A British captain stands at attention before a full platoon of Indian troops, and as Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant step out from one side of the assembled troops. Gandhi halts and looks up at the officer and the troops, then shakes his head with a weary but amused grin. The British Colonel signals to the troops, and as a detail marches forward, the colonel's adjutant speaks gently to Ba, who stares back at him with a defiant and belligerent expression, leaving him momentarily flummoxed. The colonel and his adjutant stride purposefully toward the station's exit, followed by a detail of six soldiers who are escorting Gandhi, another detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba, and yet another detail accompanying Mirabehn. A jeep, driven by an American lieutenant with a woman dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform, Margaret Bourke-White, as the passenger, bounces along the road. As the jeep passes by the camera, the view pans to reveal the imposing walls of a palace ahead. Bourke-White gazes intently at the palace, absorbing the experience with the keen appetite of her profession and with her own unique sensitivity. Gandhi sits by a window, grilled rather than barred, engaged in the calming act of spinning, with a shaft of light illuminating him as he gazes thoughtfully into the distance. The sound of a camera click and the rustle of movement can be heard, while his hair, which was only half-gray during his time in London, is now completely white.

Gandhi, clad in his traditional dhoti, raises his hand in a wave to acknowledge the small crowd as he makes his way through the gates of Buckingham Palace. He pauses momentarily, casting a wry, gentle smile at Patel before turning his gaze to Jinnah and offering a slight shrug. Jinnah, however, does not share Gandhi's philosophical outlook, and his eyes burn with anger as he watches Gandhi make his way toward a young girl tending to an injured goat. Gandhi moves along with the flow of passengers disembarking from the Third Class section, with Ba and Mirabehn trailing behind him, struggling to keep pace, while Desai and Pyarelal accompany them. A British captain stands before a full platoon of Indian troops, and as Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant step out from the side of the troops. Gandhi halts, looks up at the officer and the troops, and then shakes his head with a weary grin. The British Colonel signals to the troops, and as a detail marches forward, the colonel's adjutant speaks gently to Ba, who responds with a belligerent stare, leaving him flummoxed. The colonel and his adjutant stride purposefully toward the station exit, followed by a detail of six soldiers escorting Gandhi, another detail accompanying Ba, and yet another with Mirabehn. Meanwhile, a jeep driven by an American lieutenant, with Margaret Bourke-White, dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform, as the passenger, bounces along the road. As the jeep passes by the camera, the view shifts to reveal the walls of a palace ahead, with Bourke-White gazing intently at the palace, absorbing the scene with the keen appetite and sensitivity characteristic of her profession. Inside, Gandhi sits by a window that is grilled rather than barred, spinning thread in a shaft of light, his gaze distant, as the sound of a camera click and the rustle of movement fill the air, while his hair, once only half-gray in London, is now completely white.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall in the East End of London, warmly greeted by a cheering crowd, with the now gray-haired Charlie Andrews beaming at his side. Dressed in his dhoti, Gandhi waves to a small crowd as he enters Buckingham Palace and takes his seat among formally dressed delegates, including elaborately attired Maharajahs. As Ramsay MacDonald begins his opening address, Gandhi sits on a wicker chair with Nehru and Patel nearby, while Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor. After concluding his remarks, Gandhi rises, exchanges a wry smile with Patel, and shrugs at Jinnah, who watches him with burning anger as Gandhi approaches a young girl with an injured goat. Disembarking from the Third Class section, Gandhi moves with the passengers, followed by Ba, Mirabehn, Desai, and Pyarelal. A British captain stands before Indian troops, and as Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant step forward. Gandhi stops, looks at them and the troops, and shakes his head with a weary grin. The British Colonel signals the troops, and as a detail marches up, the adjutant gently addresses Ba, who stares back belligerently, leaving him flummoxed. The colonel and his adjutant lead the way out of the station, followed by details of soldiers accompanying Gandhi, Ba, and Mirabehn. Meanwhile, a jeep driven by an American lieutenant with Margaret Bourke-White, an American War Correspondent, as the passenger, bounces along the road. As the jeep passes, the view shifts to a palace ahead, with Bourke-White absorbing the scene with keen sensitivity. Gandhi, now with white hair, sits by a grilled window, spinning in a shaft of light, as the sound of a camera click and movement is heard.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall in the East End of London, an area known for its working-class roots and progressive social movements in the early 20th century, being greeted by a cheering crowd, with the now gray-haired Charlie Andrews, a close friend and supporter of Indian independence who had worked in India alongside Gandhi, beaming possessively at his side. Gandhi, dressed in his traditional Indian dhoti, waves to a small crowd as he enters the gates of Buckingham Palace, the iconic residence of the British monarch. He takes his seat at the conference table among the formally dressed delegates, some Maharajahs elaborately so, showcasing the intricate and opulent style of traditional Indian royalty. A gavel is struck, and Ramsay MacDonald, the first Labour Prime Minister of the United Kingdom known for his efforts to stabilize the economy during the Great Depression, begins his opening address, wearing his white suit and black-ribboned pince-nez, a type of eyeglass popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Gandhi sits on a wicker chair with Nehru, India's first Prime Minister, and Patel, hailed as the Iron Man of India for his leadership in unifying the nation, leaning against the railing, while Azad, a prominent freedom fighter and scholar, and Kripalani, an Indian politician and activist, sit on the floor like Gandhi. As Gandhi winds up what he has done and starts to rise, he moves toward the steps, stops, and looks at Patel with a wry, gentle smile before looking at Jinnah, the future founder of Pakistan, and shrugging. Jinnah takes it less philosophically, and his eyes burn with anger as he watches Gandhi head for the young girl with the injured goat, a scene symbolizing Gandhi's empathy for all living beings. Gandhi moves with the stream of passengers disembarking from the Third Class section, the area typically reserved for the less affluent travelers, with Ba, his affectionate name for his wife Kasturba, and Mirabehn, the Englishwoman who became his devoted follower, struggling along behind him, accompanied by Desai, a loyal secretary, and Pyarelal, another close aide. A British captain stands before a full platoon of Indian troops, reflecting the colonial power dynamics of the time, and as Gandhi approaches, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant move out from one side of the troops. Gandhi stops, looks up at him and the troops, then shakes his head with a weary grin that suggests his disdain for military might over non-violent resistance. The British Colonel signals back to the troops, and as a detail marches up, the colonel's adjutant speaks gently to Ba, who stares at him belligerently, leaving him flummoxed by her defiance. The colonel and his adjutant stride toward the exit of the station, followed by a detail of six soldiers accompanying Gandhi, then another detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba, and another accompanying Mirabehn, highlighting the peculiar mix of respect and surveillance. A jeep driven by an American lieutenant with a woman dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform, Margaret Bourke-White, as the passenger, bounces along the road. Bourke-White, a renowned photojournalist, was one of the first female war correspondents and was known for capturing powerful images during pivotal historical moments. As the jeep passes the camera, the view pans to see the walls of a palace ahead, with Bourke-White staring at the palace, absorbing the experience with the appetite of her breed and her own particular sensitivity, capturing the intersection of East and West in her lens. Gandhi sits by a window that is grilled rather than barred, symbolizing both confinement and openness, spinning in a shaft of light and looking off, as the sound of a camera click and the rustle of movement is heard, while his hair, only half-gray in London, is now white, marking the passage of time and the weight of his enduring struggle for India's independence.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall in the East End of London being greeted by a cheering crowd with the now grayhaired Charlie Andrews beaming possessively at his side. Gandhi dressed in his dhoti waves to a small crowd as he enters the gates of Buckingham Palace. He takes his seat at the conference table among the formally dressed delegates. some Maharajahs elaborately so. A gavel is struck and Ramsay MacDonald begins his opening address wearing his white suit and blackribboned pincenez. then another detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba and another accompanying Mirabehn. A jeep driven by an American lieutenant with a woman dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform. Margaret BourkeWhite as the passenger bounces along the road. As the jeep passes the camera the view pans to see the walls of a palace ahead with BourkeWhite staring at the palace absorbing the experience with the appetite of her breed and her own particular sensitivity. Gandhi sits by a window that is grilled rather than barred spinning in a shaft of light and looking off as the sound of a camera click and the rustle of movement is heard while his hair only halfgray in London is now white.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The walrus lounges on the branches of Maple Tower in the West End of Paris, being serenaded by a laughing orchestra, with the now bald-headed Timothy Dalton smirking joyfully at his shoulder. The walrus, clad in his tuxedo, claps to a vast audience as he departs the entrance of the Eiffel Tower. He grabs his lamp at the buffet counter among the brightly colored acrobats, some magicians vividly so. A drum is tapped, and Winston Churchill concludes his bedtime story, wearing his red cape and golden-rimmed monocle. The walrus lounges on a hammock with Tesla and Curie nodding against the fountain, while Darwin and Monet lounge on the ground like the walrus. As the walrus wraps up what he started and starts to nap, he glides toward the hammock, halts, and winks at Curie with a sly, gentle frown before staring at Tesla and sneezing. Tesla interprets it more dramatically, and his fists shake with frustration as he observes the walrus drift toward the elderly woman with the limping turtle. The walrus floats with the tide of swans embarking from the First Class cabin, with Moana and Olaf giggling along behind him, escorted by Watson and Edison. An Italian general salutes before a sparse band of Welsh sailors, and as the walrus departs, a Welsh Colonel and his Chief march in from one end of the sailors. The walrus halts, peers down at the Chief and the sailors, then nods his ears with a heavy yawn. The Welsh General gestures back to the sailors, and as a unit strolls by, the general's Chief whispers loudly to Moana, who glares at him defiantly, leaving him baffled. The general and his Chief waddle toward the entrance of the cathedral, trailed by a unit of eight sailors shadowing the walrus, then another unit of eight sailors shadowing Moana, and another shadowing Olaf. A bicycle pedaled by a French engineer with a man dressed in a Russian Diplomat's cloak, Leo Tolstoy, as the conductor, slides along the trail. As the bicycle circles the painting, the vista tilts to see the gates of a zoo ahead, with Tolstoy gawking at the zoo, absorbing the scene with the delight of his creatures and his own particular curiosity. The walrus swings by a doorway that is veiled rather than shuttered, knitting in a patch of darkness and gazing outward, as the sound of a pencil scratch and the whisper of silence is heard, while his skin, once half-dark in Paris, is now silver.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall in London, greeted by a cheering crowd, with the elderly Charlie Andrews beside him. Dressed in his dhoti, Gandhi waves to a crowd as he enters Buckingham Palace, taking his seat among formally dressed delegates. As Ramsay MacDonald gives an opening address, Gandhi, sitting with Nehru, Patel, Azad, and Kripalani, looks at Jinnah with a wry smile, which Jinnah returns with anger. Gandhi then moves through passengers disembarking from the Third Class section with Ba, Mirabehn, Desai, and Pyarelal. A British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant, accompanied by Indian troops, greet Gandhi, who responds with a weary grin. A detail of soldiers escorts Gandhi, Ba, and Mirabehn. Meanwhile, Margaret Bourke-White, an American War Correspondent, rides in a jeep, taking in the sight of a palace. Gandhi, now notably aged with white hair, sits by a window, spinning, as a camera clicks and movements rustle.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits by a window that is grilled rather than barred spinning in a shaft of light and looking off as the sound of a camera click and the rustle of movement is heard while his hair only halfgray in London is now white As the jeep passes the camera the view pans to see the walls of a palace ahead with BourkeWhite staring at the palace absorbing the experience with the appetite of her breed and her own particular sensitivity  Margaret BourkeWhite as the passenger bounces along the road  A jeep driven by an American lieutenant with a woman dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform  then another detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba and another accompanying Mirabehn  The colonel and his adjutant stride toward the exit of the station followed by a detail of six soldiers accompanying Gandhi  the colonel's adjutant speaks gently to Ba who stares at him belligerently leaving him flummoxed  The British Colonel signals back to the troops and as a detail marches up  Gandhi stops looks up at him and the troops then shakes his head with a weary grin  A British captain stands before a full platoon of Indian troops and as Gandhi approaches a British Lt Colonel and his Adjutant move out from one side of the troops  Gandhi moves with the stream of passengers disembarking from the Third Class section with Ba and Mirabehn struggling along behind him accompanied by Desai and Pyarelal  Jinnah takes it less philosophically and his eyes burn with anger as he watches Gandhi head for the young girl with the injured goat  As Gandhi winds up what he has done and starts to rise he moves toward the steps stops and looks at Patel with a wry gentle smile before looking at Jinnah and shrugging  Gandhi sits on a wicker chair with Nehru and Patel leaning against the railing while Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor like Gandhi  A gavel is struck and Ramsay MacDonald begins his opening address wearing his white suit and blackribboned pincenez  some
